utterances: Let me, let me....

There's 1.5 million refugees, Iraqi refugees,

And in all the adjacent countries, two million internal refugees displaced in the country.

left the Green Zone.

Michael, the question that sparked this part of the discussion was, was it all about oil in the first place?
And I remember I was sitting in front of a television and it was about weapons of mass destruction.
Absolutely.
So, I just ask you to - and you know, those who subscribe to your thinking, that that be considered in your discussion or in your thinking.
Well, it's more than a discussion...
Didn't Alan Greenspan...

It cannot be dismissed.

It's in his book.
Well, here's - let's say it's all about oil.

No, but this is wrong.
This is absolutely wrong.

But let me just ask this question...

We're going to have to wrap up this topic because I want to make sure and get something in, particularly because Sharon and Liza, you're in New York.
There's the video of a woman collapsing and dying in a Brooklyn, New York hospital emergency room last month.
The surveillance video shows 49-year-old Esmin Green toppling over and falling flat on her face.
It was, you know, hours before she was served, an hour before hospital employees even came to her aid.
By that time it was too late.
Liza, what's the reverb in New York of this story?
Well, you know, it's the - unfortunately, people are not shocked by it.
And I hate to say that, particularly because it's a - you know, a public-run hospital.
Anybody's who's gone to - I've actually been in the emergency room of Kingsboro Hospital - and many years ago and it traumatized me to no end.
So it's just - and it's not only the fact that she was there.
She was an immigrant also with no medical benefits.
A woman that was sending money home for her family, basically you know, supporting her whole family.
I think - I can't remember her...
Jamaican.
Jamaica.
She was from Jamaica, right.
So, her whole story, especially with how brutal - I mean, she was in New York, but this country has had such a brutal backlash against immigrants, whether documented or undocumented.

And then we have the whole economic, you know, breakdown of the health system and so it's - you know, it's almost like a microcosm - microscopic view of all what's wrong with our country when it comes to domestic policies.
And so, you know, it's unfortunate that, you know, you look at her situation and you say yeah, that happens a lot in our country.
I'm going to have to keep it tight with you guys, Liza and Michael.
Michael first.
Do you think that this is a microcosm as, you know - I mean Sharon and Michael, do you think it's a microcosm, as Liza says, or is it a random incident?

No, I think it's more than a random incident.

Kings Drew.
It was an emergency room.
Ms. Green, Esmin Green was in the psychiatric unit of Kings County hospital.
And yes the hospital has had some serious problems in the past.
But it really is a testament to that poor people really have it bad when it comes to healthcare.
But poor people with mental health issues really, really have it bad.
I have to give Michael the last word.
Sorry.

I think sadly this is kind of one of those - what struck me is that people are - should be traumatized, but there is a certain expectation that we believe that people have the right to sleep in public places.
And I think the reason this could be overlooked is because we have gotten used to seeing people sleeping in public places and we don't know if they're alive or dead.
Well guys, on that sobering note, I want to thank you all for our Roundtable today.
Thank you.
Michael D.
Cobb Bowen, is the creator of cobb.typepad.com.
